results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [event version]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DV and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This is the event version of ‘Cyberthon-III: the underground connection’ to see the [1 hour compilation] see title B2004315

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [1-hour compilation]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DV and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This one-hour compilation was created a month after the event from nine hours of footage and subsequently aired July 12, 1992.

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

results.title: Cyberthon I: For the Mind, Body and Soul
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ was the first guerrilla TV broadcast event of its namesake following the success of the Cyberdelia broadcast a year earlier. Conceptualised as a ‘marathon cyber’ event, ‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ saw a group of artists broadcast, remix, VJ and DJ mastered footage, experimental Amiga graphics and electronic art alongside performers and a live band at RMITV’s studio in Melbourne. Collaborator and curator to the events, Adem Jaffers said this is where the Cyberthon events really began and over the next four years they would expand in scope to feature over 300 VJ’s, DJ’s, artists, performers and collaborators. 

Visual Artists: Nuero (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent, Dale Nason and Elena Popa), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Interscreen (Kimberley Hughes), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac and Terence ‘H20’ Ho), Third Eye (Ollie Olsen), Acid Death Bed (Darren Porter and Paul Wain), Baby Lemonade Lemar (Andrea), Captain ROM

Performers: Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki

‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Crikey There's a Tractor On the Farm
results.creator_credit: Comedia Productions, Stephen Mepham and Robert Grant
results.brief_description: An entertaining look at the need for safety precautions with farm tractors including the use of seatbelts and ear muffs. Written by Robert Grant. Cast: Maurie Fields, Simon Thorpe.

results.title: Escape from Woomera
results.brief_description: Escape from Woomera is a videogame that asks players to experience Australia’s draconian immigration policies from the point-of-view of a refugee. By combining game mechanics, art and activism, Escape from Woomera goes beyond the razor wire and detention centre media blackout.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description:
If you thought escaping from Castle Wolfenstein was hard, try Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre…

With a first person, 3D adventure game we invite gamers to assume the character of, and ‘live’ through the experiences of a modern day refugee. The effective media lock-out from immigration detention centres has meant that the whole truth about what goes on behind the razor-wire at Woomera, Baxter, Port Hedland, Maribyrnong and Villawood remains largely a mystery to the Australian public. We want to challenge this by offering the world a glimpse - more than that even: an interactive, immersive experience - of life within the most secretive and controversial places on the Australian political and geographical landscape. In this way, Escape From Woomera will be an engine for mobilising experiences and situations otherwise inaccessible to an nation of disempowered onlookers. It will provide both a portal and a toolkit for reworking and engaging with what is otherwise an entirely mediated current affair.

Lead artist/Environment artist: Stephen Honegger

Level designer: Ian Malcolm

Investigative journalist: Kate Wild

Cutscene artist: Morgan Simpson

Creative director: Katharine Neil

Animators: Andrea Blundell, Chris Markwart

Producers: Justin Halliday, Mark Angeli

Executive producer: Julian Oliver

Admin: Rani Kellock

Programming: Matthew Jones, David Jewsbury, Duncan Murray

Additional programming: Katharine Neil

UI art and website: Monique Jones

QA: Alex McNeilly

results.title: Solar dawn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Solarscope Films, Gareth Cole and Kay Roberts
results.brief_description: Utilises many animation sequences to clearly show how basic solar collectors work. It shows how buildings can be heated and cooled by solar devices, and how city buildings and ordinary houses should be designed to take advantage of direct solar energy.

results.title: Land use and abuse
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Damien Parer and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows the impact of careless land development on the Tasmanian environment and goes on to stress the need for conservationists and developers to work together. Narrated by Stewart Faichney.

results.title: Here They Know You
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “School’s Out”.
In country towns, opportunities for school leavers are limited. Diane and Peter have left school but don’t have jobs. They reflect on the relevance of school, the sense of community in a country town and the advantages of city and country life

results.title: William Buelow Gould
results.brief_description: Looks at the Australian artist William Buelow Gould and his survival as a convict painter in the harsh environment of mid 19th Century colonial Australia

results.title: You Just Don't Realise
results.creator_credit: Eyewitness News and Philippe de Montignie
results.brief_description: In Australia, where there is one vehicle for every three people, road accidents have reached epidemic proportions with 4,000 people dying each year. The trauma of the accidents themselves is only eclipsed by the trauma of the chain of events that follow. Highly graphic scenes of car accidents in this film make viewing unsuitable for sensitive people, and preview is strongly recommended
